The effect of metal doping (Ce, Fe, and Co) on CO tolerance of Mn/Ti catalyst used for eliminating NO from sintering flue gas has been investigated. The best MnCe/Ti catalyst achieves a NO x conversion of 80 % from 125 to 250 °C at a GHSV of 80,000 h−1. NO x conversion dropped by only 4 % below 200 °C and N2 selectivity slightly increased after introduction of CO, indicating strong resistance of MnCe/Ti catalyst to CO. XPS results suggest that CO oxidation does not alter surface content of Mn4+ and Ce3+ sites of used MnCe/Ti catalyst while it reduces the surface adsorbed oxygen of used MnCe/Ti catalyst because surface adsorbed oxygen consumed by CO oxidation cannot be readily replenished owing to the insufficient capacity in oxygen and electron transport. This is primarily accountable for the slight decrease in NO x conversion. Furthermore, NH3 can completely restrain CO adsorption on MnCe/Ti catalyst while CO cannot hinder the adsorption of NH3 and NO on the catalyst because the interaction between CO and MnCe/Ti catalyst significantly weakened in the presence of NH3, leading to the strong CO tolerance of MnCe/Ti. On MnCe/Ti Eley-Rideal mechanism governs the NH3-SCR involving gaseous NO and adsorbed NH3, while Mars-van Krevelen mechanism describes the oxidation of CO, indicating its reaction with gaseous CO and surface adsorbed oxygen. The findings in this paper can provide modification strategy for low-temperature SCR catalysts which are expected to be applied for sintering flue gas. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MnCe/Ti Low-temperature NH3-SCR CO tolerance Mechanism In situ DRIFTS Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Up to now, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO by NH3 is a technology commonly used for flue gas cleaning [1–3]. The commercial V/TiO2 catalysts mainly used for removing NO in coal-fired flue gas only have high catalytic performance between 300 and 400 °C, which cannot satisfy the activity requirement for NO removal from sintering flue gas because of the lower discharge temperature (< 200 °C) [4–8]. Beside, there is a marked difference in flue gas composition between coal-fired flue gas and sintering flue gas. For instance, sintering flue gas typically contains a CO concentration ranging from 0.6 to 1.2 %, which is considerably elevated in comparison to the CO levels found in flue gas emissions from coal-fired power plants. This distinct difference may affect the denitration performance. Consequently, scientific investigations have been conducted to analyze the impact of CO on the low-temperature NH3-SCR. Liu et al. [9] studied the impact of CO on the NH3-SCR on CrO x -CeO2 binary oxide and the results indicated that this catalyst exhibits high NH3-SCR performance. However, the impact of CO on the reaction route between NH3 and NO is still not known. Liu et al. [10] proposed the phosphorus-modified CuCeZr catalyst to simultaneously remove NO and CO, which can realize NO x conversion of 90 % between 200 and 350 °C. Beside, the carbonate species and surface lattice oxygen are considered as the reactive species during CO oxidation. It was reported that CO can restrain NO to be adsorbed and oxidized on Sb0.5CeZr2O x catalyst, resulting in the decrease of SCR performance [11]. Wang et al. [12] synthesized some Mn-based nanorod catalysts for NO reduction and CO oxidation and the results showed that α-MnO2-Cu nanorod catalyst achieved over 85 % NO x and CO conversion. However, CO had a detrimental impact on NO adsorption and also reduced the N2 selectivity. It was observed that NH3 had a restraining effect on the oxidation of CO, while NO actually promoted the oxidation of CO. Furthermore, several studies have suggested that CO is capable of adsorbing onto active sites on the catalyst surface and consuming oxygen species during the CO oxidation [13–15]. The above analysis indicates that NH3, NO and CO can compete with each other, resulting in a highly intricate reactions involved in the NO reduction and CO oxidation. The Mn-based catalysts are promised as candidates owing to its abundant acid sites, strong redox property, plenty of active oxygen, and variable valence states [16–18]. The addition of extra metal elements is a widely employed method to control and adjust the physicochemical characteristics of manganese-based catalysts, such as redox properties, acidity, and mobility of oxygen and electrons. For instance, the presence of Ce or Fe in catalysts can affect the adsorption and oxidation of CO [13,19,20]. Consequently, these modifications can regulate adsorption properties and reaction route [21–24]. Furthermore, our previous research findings indicate that by modifying the manganese-based catalysts, not only can we enhance their performance, but we can also alter the reaction pathway taken by the reactants during the reduction of NO [25,26]. For instance, NO has the exceptional ability to directly interact with the adsorbed NH3 on catalyst surface without the prerequisite of initially adsorbing on the catalyst surface. This remarkable attribute empowers the catalyst to bolster its resistance against CO poisoning. To obtain highly efficient SCR catalyst with strong CO tolerance, the modified Mn/TiO2 catalysts are developed for NO removal since it is anticipated that the improvement of acidity, reducibility, and transport of electron and oxygen will lead to a decrease in inhibitory impact of CO on NO reduction. Herein, we focused on the impact of modifications on CO tolerance of Mn-based catalysts for NH3-SCR. Tests are conducted to investigate SCR activity of the modified catalysts and the impact of CO on the selectivity of N2 and NO x conversion. To gain insights into the underlying mechanisms, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to determine the oxidation states and relative contents of the active components in both fresh and used catalysts. Furthermore, in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) was adopted to explore the action mechanism of CO. Based on our findings, it is able to propose interaction mechanism between CO oxidation and NO reduction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The modified Mn/Ti catalysts were obtained via the impregnation method with assistance of ultrasonic wave [21], which were designated as MnM/Ti (M=Ce, Fe, Co). The support is TiO2 (P25, Degussa) and the precursors of active species are metal nitrates. According to our previous work [21,26], the optimal loading amounts of Mn and M are 20 % and 10 %, respectively. For comparison, Mn/Ti catalyst was also prepared. The catalysts were ground and sieved before performance testing to obtain particles of 40–60 mesh. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The K-Alpha Spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) was employed to perform the XPS analysis. The binding energies were corrected using the C 1s value of 284.8 eV. For in situ DRIFTS measurements, a Nicolet IS50 FTIR Spectrometer was utilized. Background spectra were acquired at specific temperatures in a N2 flow. These background spectra were subtracted from sample spectra at the corresponding temperature. 2.3 NH3-SCR testing The performance tests were carried out using a fixed-bed experimental system, operating at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 80,000 h−1 with a reactant gas of 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, 1 vol.% CO, 15 vol.% O2, 5 vol.% H2O (when used) and carrier N2. In each test, the temperature of the sample was ramped from 100 °C to 300 °C and the concentrations of NH3, CO, NO2, NO, CO2, and N2O were continuously analyzed using a Gasmet DX4000 flue gas analyzer. However, the recorded values were only considered when the concentrations reached a steady state. The conversion and selectivity were analyzed using the formulas below: N O x / CO conversion = [ NO x / CO ] in − [ NO x / CO ] out [ NO x / CO ] in × 100 % N 2 selectivity = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ N O x ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ N O x ] out − [ N H 3 ] out ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic behavior As depicted in Fig. 1 a, both the Mn/Ti and MnM/Ti catalysts exhibit the same trend in NO x conversion when exposed to flue gas containing CO. Initially, the NO x conversions increased with increasing temperature, reaching a peak at 200 °C. However, beyond this temperature, the conversions started to decrease. Importantly, comparing to the Mn/Ti catalyst, the modified Mn/Ti catalysts demonstrated significantly higher NO x conversions, pointing again to that the doping of the secondary metal element can still improve the catalytic performance despite the presence of CO. Furthermore, MnCe/Ti catalyst exhibits the best NO x conversion below 200 °C in comparison to other modified Mn/Ti catalysts. With the best MnCe/Ti catalyst NO x conversion of over 80 % is achieved between 125 and 250 °C which covers the exhaust temperature of sintering flue gas. To study the impact of CO on NO x conversion over the best MnCe/Ti catalyst, the MnCe/Ti and Mn/Ti catalysts were further tested under gas flow without CO for comparison (Fig. 1b). The introduction of CO resulted in the significant drop in NO x conversion over Mn/Ti catalyst, in which NO x conversion decreased by at least 11 % at 100 °C and at most 34 % at 150 °C. However, for MnCe/Ti catalyst, NO x conversion slightly decreased by only 4 % below 200 °C in the presence of CO. The downward trend is increasingly obvious above 200 °C and the NO x conversion dropped by at most 18 % at 300 °C. The inhibitory impact of CO on NO x conversion over MnCe/Ti catalyst became much less marked below 200 °C compared to that on Mn/Ti catalyst, suggesting that CO tolerance of MnCe/Ti catalyst is significantly enhanced following Ce doping. Furthermore, NO x conversion by individual CO-SCR in the presence of O2 is given in Fig. S1. It can be seen that CO-SCR over MnCe/Ti catalyst can happen in the presence of high-concentration O2. However, the CO-SCR only contributed 3–20 % NO x conversion for NO reduction. In addition, the actual proportion may decrease because NO may preferentially react with NH3 in the presence of NH3 and O2. When examining the CO conversions of both MnCe/Ti and Mn/Ti catalysts (Fig. 1c), they both exhibit a nearly linear increase when raising temperature from 100 to 300 °C. Additionally, CO conversion of MnCe/Ti catalyst exhibits a slight decrease below 200 °C and a slight increase above 200 °C compared to that of Mn/Ti catalyst, pointing to that Ce doping has no markedly influence on CO oxidation. It can be observed in Fig. 1d that the presence of CO had almost no impact on N2 selectivity of MnCe/Ti catalyst while it resulted in a slight increase in N2 selectivity over Mn/Ti catalyst below 200 °C. However, CO markedly promoted N2 selectivities of the catalysts above 200 °C. Besides, MnCe/Ti catalyst possesses higher N2 selectivity below 250 °C in comparison to Mn/Ti catalyst when CO is present in flue gas. Considering that sintering flue gas usually contains a certain amount of moisture. The influence of H2O on CO resistance should be studied. It can be seen in Fig. S2a that the decrease of NO x conversion over MnCe/Ti catalyst after introduction of CO in the presence of H2O is slightly lower than that in the absence of H2O below 200 °C. While the decrease of NO x conversion over MnCe/Ti catalyst after introduction of CO in the presence of H2O is almost the same as that in the absence of H2O above 200 °C. Furthermore, it can be observed that H2O significantly decreased the NO x conversion below 200 °C while it almost had no impact on NO x conversion above 200 °C. This may be due to that H2O can compete with other flue gas component to adsorb on catalyst surface at low temperature and it is difficult to adsorb on catalyst surface at relative high temperature. To further confirm this inference, the transient reaction experiment was carried out and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. S2b. The introduction of H2O resulted in the sharp decrease of NO x conversion and the NO x conversion quickly recovered to its initial level after H2O was removed from flue gas. This verifies that there exists the competitive adsorption between H2O and the other flue gas component at low temperature. Therefore, the presence of H2O in flue gas may inhibit the adsorption of CO on the surface of MnCe/Ti catalyst, which reduced the inhibiting effect of CO on NO x conversion over MnCe/Ti catalyst and thus slightly enhanced the CO resistance of MnCe/Ti catalyst. MnCe/Ti catalyst exhibits glorious NO x conversion and strong CO tolerance at low temperature. Therefore, the following studies on CO tolerance mainly focused on the best MnCe/Ti catalyst. 3.2 XPS characterization Fig. 2 illustrates XPS spectra of both the fresh and spent catalysts. The corresponding relative concentrations of Mn4+, Ce3+, and O ions, as determined from the characteristic peaks area ratio, are presented in Table 1 . Two main peaks in Mn 2p spectra arise from Mn 2p1/2 (around 653.0 eV) and Mn 2p3/2 (around 641.3 eV) (Fig. 2a). These two peaks could be deconvoluted into three superimposed sub-peaks being characteristic for Mn3+ (640.7–640.8 eV), Mn4+ (642.0 eV), and Mn2+ (644.5–644.7 eV) species [23,24]. Table 1 shows that surface Mn4+/Mn ratio rose from 0.35 for fresh MnCe/Ti catalyst to 0.37 for MnCe/Ti catalyst after pretreatment with SCR (NO + NH3 + O2) while it slightly dropped to 0.34 for MnCe/Ti catalyst pretreated with SCR/CO. This indicates that the reduced Mn3+ sites on MnCe/Ti catalyst were quickly reoxidized by gaseous O2 when CO is absent. Besides, surface Mn/Ti ratio of fresh MnCe/Ti catalyst decreased from 0.29 to 0.22 and 0.24 for SCR-pretreated MnCe/Ti catalyst and MnCe/Ti catalyst pretreated with SCR/CO, respectively. This indicates that MnO x species on spent MnCe/Ti catalysts may agglomerate during the SCR process. The Ce 3d spectra were deconvoluted into eight sub-peaks for optimum fitting (Fig. 2b). The peaks designated as u (900.4 eV), u’’ (906.4 eV), u’’’ (916.4 eV), v (881.9 eV), v’’ (887.9 eV), and v’’’ (897.9 eV) are referred to Ce4+ while the rest peaks of u’ (903.9 eV) and v’ (885.4 eV) are typical for Ce3+ [27,28]. The surface Ce3+/Ce ratio of fresh MnCe/Ti catalyst markedly dropped from 0.48 to 0.36 after reaction, pointing to the decrease of surface oxygen vacancy of spent MnCe/Ti catalysts. Interestingly, surface Ce/Ti ratios before and after pretreatment remained unchanged, pointing to high dispersion of Ce species during SCR reaction. The O 1 s spectra can be deconvoluted into two peaks (Fig. 2c) being characteristic for surface chemisorbed oxygen (designated as Oα, 532.3 eV) and lattice oxygen (Oβ, 530.0–530.1 eV) [25,29]. As shown in Table 1, both the surface Oα/O and O/Ti ratios of spent MnCe/Ti catalysts remarkably dropped compared to those of fresh catalyst, pointing to the decrease in concentrations of Oα on spent catalysts. This is well consistent with the previously mentioned decrease in surface oxygen vacancy. Additionally, the surface Oα/O and O/Ti ratios of the SCR/CO-pretreated catalyst were lower than those of the catalyst after pretreatment with individual SCR. This suggests that CO oxidation over the MnCe/Ti catalyst further contributes to the decrease in Oα in the spent MnCe/Ti catalyst. 3.3 In situ DRIFTS studies 3.3.1 Reaction with NO and NH3 in the absence of CO MnCe/Ti catalyst exhibits excellent CO tolerance below 200 °C. Therefore, in situ experiments were performed at 150 °C. Reaction process between NO and NH3 on MnCe/Ti catalyst when CO is absent was studied first. As depicted in Fig. 3 a, after exposure to NH3 and subsequent purging with N2, six stable bands were formed which are referred to amide (-NH2) species (1558 cm−1) [30,31], NH4 + species (1433 and 1365 cm−1) [11,32], and coordinated NH3 (1258, 1208, and 1174 cm−1) [28,32,33]. After 2 min in NO + O2/N2 flow, the preadsorbed –NH2, NH3 and NH4 + completely vanished, indicating that these preadsorbed NH3 species are reactive intermediates. After the disappearance of preadsorbed NH3 species, five new bands arose which stemmed from bidentate nitrate (1567, 1277, and 1022 cm−1) [34,35], monodentate nitrite (1193 cm−1) [36], and bridged nitrate (1604 cm−1) [28]. The band at 1193 cm−1 of nitrite gradually disappeared, accompanied by the gradual increase in residual bands of nitrate species, indicating that the monodentate nitrite would be transformed to nitrate species. After MnCe/Ti catalyst was subjected to NO/O2 treatment (Fig. 3b), bands at 1603, 1567, 1272, and 1017 cm−1 of nitrate species appeared. Besides, an additional band at 1368 cm−1 referred to a nitro compound [36] was observed. Subsequently, the pretreated catalyst was exposed to NH3. After 30 min, the bands of bridged and bidentate nitrates only slightly decreased while the band of nitro compound maintained nearly unchanged, pointing to the weak interaction between adsorbed NH3 and nitrate and that the nitro compound acts as a nonreactive intermediate. Comparing the results in Fig. 3a and b, it can be inferred that gaseous NO rather than nitrate can preferentially reacts with adsorbed NH3, pointing to that Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism governs NH3-SCR on MnCe/Ti catalyst. The DRIFT spectra for NH3-SCR over Mn/Ti catalyst in the absence of CO are shown in Fig. S3. The results indicated that SCR over Mn/Ti catalyst mainly follows E-R mechanism because the reaction of preadsorbed nitrate species with NH3 was very slow. 3.3.2 Impact of CO on NH3 adsorption After 30 min exposure to NH3/N2, three small bands at 1558, 1433, and 1365 cm−1 and a broad band at 1174 cm−1 are created (Fig. 4 a), which are referred to –NH2, NH4 +, and NH3 species mentioned above. Subsequently, the MnCe/Ti catalyst was purged by N2, leading to the obvious decrease of the band at 1174 cm−1 and the emergence of two bands at 1258 and 1208 cm−1 of coordinated NH3. This indicates that the large band at 1174 cm−1 stemmed from the overlap of several bands at the same region and the weakly adsorbed NH3 species were removed after purging. After flowing NH3 + CO/N2 for 30 min, four same bands at 1560, 1355, 1206, and 1169 cm−1 were created (Fig. 4b). In addition, two new bands assigned to carbonate species (1512 and 1072 cm−1) [37,38] appeared. Subsequently, purging the NH3/CO-pretreated MnCe/Ti catalyst with N2 resulted in the decline of bands of coordinated NH3 and the disappearance of carbonate species, suggesting that part of adsorbed NH3 and carbonate species weakly bonded on MnCe/Ti catalyst surface and are easy to desorb. To easily compare DRIFT spectra of the pretreated MnCe/Ti catalysts, the DRIFT spectra of NH3-pretreated and NH3/CO-pretreated MnCe/Ti catalysts are simultaneously presented in Fig. 4c. DRIFT spectrum of the NH3/CO-pretreated MnCe/Ti catalyst is nearly the same as that of the MnCe/Ti catalyst pretreated with individual NH3. Furthermore, the strong bands of carbonate species in DRIFT spectrum for separate CO adsorption did not appear in DRIFT spectrum of the MnCe/Ti catalyst pretreated by NH3/CO. These indicate that CO in flue gas did not affect NH3 to be adsorbed on MnCe/Ti catalyst but NH3 completely hindered CO to be adsorbed on MnCe/Ti catalyst. For comparison, Fig. 4d shows DRIFT spectra of NH3-pretreated and NH3/CO-pretreated Mn/Ti catalysts. The main band at 1209 cm−1 of adsorbed NH3 under NH3 flow alone was not observed in the DRIFT spectrum under NH3/CO flow, indicating that CO remarkably restrained NH3 adsorption on Mn/Ti catalyst. Therefore, the Ce doping can markedly reduce the inhibition effect of CO. 3.3.3 Impact of CO on NO/O2 adsorption As shown in Fig. 5 a, after 5 min in NO + O2/N2 flow, nitrate species (1603, 1567, 1272, and 1017 cm−1) mentioned above (Fig. 3) were formed on MnCe/Ti catalyst. The bands of nitrate species increased over time and a new band attributed to nitro compound was detected after 20 min in NO + O2/N2 flow. All these bands maintained nearly unchanged after purging with N2. After flowing NO + CO + O2/N2 for 30 min and subsequent sweep with N2, the identical peaks at 1602, 1560, and 1278 cm−1 were still created, whereas the band at 1368 cm−1 disappeared (Fig. 5b). Furthermore, two additional peaks at 1120 and 1027 cm−1 arose. To compare the DRIFT spectra stemmed from the pretreatment in different flows, these DRIFT spectra are simultaneously shown in Fig. 5c. Comparing these spectra, it can be deduced that bands at 1120 and 1027 cm−1 stemmed from carbonate [39,40]. Besides, the nitrate bands at 1603 and 1567 cm−1 markedly decreased when CO is present. Conversely, the peak at 1272 cm−1 remarkably increased as a result of the superposition signals from nitrate and carbonate species in the same region. This indicates that simultaneous adsorption of NO and CO on MnCe/Ti catalyst happened and CO markedly suppressed NO to be adsorbed on MnCe/Ti catalyst. For comparison, the DRIFT spectra for the influence of CO on NO adsorption over Mn/Ti catalyst are given in Fig. S4. It can be seen that NO and CO can be simultaneously adsorbed on Mn/Ti catalyst and CO did not affect the adsorption of NO. 3.3.4 Impact of CO on the reaction with NO/O2 and adsorbed NH3 When the MnCe/Ti catalyst pretreated with NH3/CO was treated with NO + O2 (Fig. 6 a), a similar behavior happened as observed when it was first exposed to NH3 and subsequent to NO + O2, in which bands of adsorbed NH3 vanished quickly while bands corresponding to nitrate and nitrite appeared. The peak at 1191 cm−1 of nitrite gradually vanished as a result of its transformation to nitrate. The bands at 1564 and 1273 cm−1 of nitrate gradually enhanced. In Fig. 6b, after 10 min in NO + O2/N2 flow, bands at 1602 and 1015 cm−1 emerged. Beside, no bands of carbonate species are created in any of the DRIFT spectra (Fig. 6a and b). This further confirms that NH3 in flue gas completely prevents CO from being adsorbed onto the MnCe/Ti catalyst. After MnCe/Ti catalyst with adsorbed NH3 was subjected to NO/CO/O2 for 1 min (Fig. 6c), the bands of adsorbed NH3 completely vanished and the same changing process of bands of adsorbed nitrite, nitrate, and carbonate happened as observed when exposure to NO/CO/O2, pointing to that the reaction with NO and adsorbed NH3 was not disturbed by gaseous CO. The DRIFT spectra for the influence of CO on the reaction with NO/O2 and adsorbed NH3 over Mn/Ti catalyst are given in Fig. S5. The results indicates that gaseous CO also does not interfere with the reaction of gaseous NO with preadsorbed NH3. 3.3.5 Influence of CO on the reaction with NH3 and preadsorbed NO/O2 When the MnCe/Ti catalyst pretreated with NO/CO was subjected to NH3 (Fig. 7 a), the bands at 1600 and 1560 cm−1 of nitrate decreased only a little. Beside, the bands at 1120 and 1027 cm−1 of carbonate maintained unchanged because carbonate cannot react with gaseous NH3. The decrease in intensities of the peaks at 1600 and 1560 cm−1 is lower than that of these peaks in Fig. 3b because the surface content of nitrate on MnCe/Ti catalyst pretreated with NO/CO/O2 is less than that on the catalyst pretreated with NO/O2 due to the inhibitory effect of CO on NO adsorption. Interestingly, the band at 1278 cm−1 maintained stable, indicating that this overlapped band mainly stemmed from adsorbed carbonate species. When the NO/O2-pretreated MnCe/Ti catalyst was subjected to NH3/CO (Fig. 7b), a similar behavior occurred as observed after exposure to individual NH3 flow (Fig. 3b), where the peaks corresponding to nitrate slightly dropped and the peak of nitro compound maintained stable. This confirms that the reaction with NH3 and preadsorbed nitrate was not affected by gaseous CO. In addition, the DRIFT spectra for influence of CO on the reaction with NH3 and preadsorbed NO/O2 over Mn/Ti catalyst are shown in Fig. S6. It can be found that the preadsorbed nitrate species are much easier to react with gaseous CO compared with the preadsorbed nitrate formed on MnCe/Ti catalyst. Interestingly, the nitro compound became reactive intermediates against CO attack. 3.3.6 Impact of CO on the co-adsorption of NO/NH3/O2 For comparison, DRIFT spectra (Fig. 8 a) for MnCe/Ti catalyst exposed to SCR atmosphere without CO were first provided. After exposure to NO + NH3 + O2, five bands were detected, in which the bands at 1602, 1552, 1267, and 1017 cm−1 belong to nitrate and the band at 1193 cm−1 is indicative of nitrite. Over time, the bands corresponding to nitrate species gradually increased, whereas the band corresponding to nitrite species gradually diminished. The changing process of these bands is in accordance with what was observed when the MnCe/Ti catalyst was treated with NO/O2 after preadsorption of NH3 (Fig. 3a). Besides, no NH3 species appeared. This is because adsorbed NH3 was quickly consumed by gaseous NO and thus did not accumulate on the catalyst. This further confirmed that adsorbed NH3 easily undergoes a reaction with gaseous NO rather than adsorbed nitrate, resulting in the deposition of nitrate species on MnCe/Ti catalyst. Fig. 8b shows DRIFT spectra for MnCe/Ti catalyst exposed to SCR + CO atmosphere. Following exposure to NO + NH3 + CO + O2, the same bands associated with nitrate species are observed, consistent with the findings in SCR conditions without CO. Interestingly, no bands of carbonate species were formed after exposure to SCR + CO, pointing again to that the presence of NH3 completely hinders CO to be adsorbed on MnCe/Ti catalyst. This is in accordance with conclusion drawn regarding the co-adsorption of NH3 and CO presented in Fig. 4c. For comparison, the DRIFT spectra for the influence of CO on the co-adsorption of NO/NH3/O2 over Mn/Ti catalyst are shown in Fig. S7. It can be observed that the band at 1506 cm−1 of carbonate species [38] and the band at 1369 cm−1 of nitro compound appeared under SCR/CO flow, indicating that CO can be adsorbed on Mn/Ti catalyst under SCR/CO atmosphere. 4 Discussion To mitigate the hindering impact of CO, which is prevalent in sintering flue gas, on NO reduction with NH3 on Mn-based catalyst, MnM/Ti catalysts with modifications are employed for NO elimination amid CO presence since it is anticipated that the modification can regulate the acidity and redox of Mn/Ti catalyst. Among all the modified MnM/Ti catalysts, MnCe/Ti catalyst possesses best catalytic performance below 200 °C. The MnCe/Ti catalyst achieved NO x conversion exceeding 80 % from 125 to 250 °C while operating at a GHSV of 80,000 h−1, even in the presence of CO, making it suitable for application in sintering flue gas treatment where the catalyst can effectively operate at the exhaust temperature of the flue gas. NO x conversion of Mn/Ti catalyst markedly dropped between 100 and 300 °C after introduction of CO while that of MnCe/Ti catalyst dropped only a little below 200 °C. Remarkably, NO x conversion of MnCe/Ti catalyst reduced by only 4 % below 200 °C while that of Mn/Ti catalyst dropped by at least 11 % at 100 °C and at most 34 % at 150 °C in the presence of CO. Moreover, the addition of CO to the flue gas resulted in an enhanced N2 selectivity of the MnCe/Ti catalyst, especially above 200 °C. And MnCe/Ti catalyst exhibits higher N2 selectivity below 250 °C in comparison to Mn/Ti catalyst. Therefore, MnCe/Ti catalyst showed strong resistance to CO. To investigate the potential explanation for the CO tolerance of MnCe/Ti catalyst, the surface chemical states and relative contents of fresh and spent MnCe/Ti catalysts were characterized using XPS. The atomic ratios of surface Mn4+/Ti and Ce3+/Ti of the fresh MnCe/Ti catalyst were found to be 0.103 and 0.072, respectively. After SCR pretreatment, these ratios decreased to 0.079 (Mn4+/Ti) and 0.054 (Ce3+/Ti) on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, these ratios were changed to 0.080 and 0.054, respectively, after pretreatment with SCR/CO. Although the ratios of surface Mn4+/Ti and Ce3+/Ti slightly decreased after SCR reaction, the ratios for SCR/CO-pretreated catalyst remained almost equivalent to that of SCR-pretreated catalyst, suggesting that CO oxidation over MnCe/Ti catalyst did not significantly alter the content of Mn4+ and Ce3+on the spent catalyst. Therefore, CO oxidation did not reduce active sites on the catalyst. Additionally, the surface Oα/Ti ratios of MnCe/Ti catalyst pretreated with SCR and the catalyst after pretreatment with SCR/CO were determined to be 0.532 and 0.337, respectively, which are both remarkably lower than that (1.022) for fresh MnCe/Ti catalyst, indicating that surface adsorbed oxygen of the spent MnCe/Ti catalysts decreased. On the one hand, MnO x species on the spent MnCe/Ti catalysts may generate agglomeration, which is verified by the decrease of surface Mn/Ti ratios for the spent MnCe/Ti catalysts. On the other hand, the surface oxygen vacancies of the spent MnCe/Ti catalysts decreased, which is indicated by the decrease of surface Ce3+/Ti ratios for the spent MnCe/Ti catalysts compared to that for the fresh catalyst, leading to less oxygen species formed on spent MnCe/Ti catalysts. All these resulted in the lower contents of surface adsorbed oxygen on spent MnCe/Ti catalysts. Furthermore, the surface adsorbed oxygen of the MnCe/Ti catalyst, which underwent SCR/CO pretreatment, decreased even more compared to that of the MnCe/Ti catalyst which only underwent SCR pretreatment. CO oxidation over MnCe/Ti catalyst consumed large amount of surface adsorbed oxygen which cannot be readily replenished by gaseous O2. This limitation arises because of the poor capacity in oxygen and electron transport, which is confirmed by the decrease of surface Mn4+/Mn ratio of the spent MnCe/Ti catalyst after pretreatment with SCR + CO. The surface adsorbed oxygen exhibits strong oxidation capacity [28], which can favor the dehydrogenation of NH3 to generate –NH2 species [22]. These species are reactive intermediates, being confirmed by DRIFT spectra results (Fig. 3a), that can further interact with gaseous NO. As a result, the decrease of surface adsorbed oxygen reduces the generation of –NH2 species and consequently reduces the NO x conversion. Moreover, the overoxidation of adsorbed NH3 was also reduced due to the decline in surface adsorbed oxygen. Therefore, the slight drop in NO x conversion and the increase in N2 selectivity are mainly attributed to the decrease in surface adsorbed oxygen of the spent MnCe/Ti catalyst caused by CO oxidation. The inhibition mechanism of CO was further explored using in situ DRIFTS experiments. The initial step was to analyze NH3-SCR mechanism when CO is not present. The spectroscopic results (Fig. 3) revealed that on MnCe/Ti catalyst NH3-SCR proceeds mainly through an E-R mechanism because adsorbed NH3 has a higher reactivity towards gaseous NO rather than adsorbed nitrate, which was further evidenced by DRIFT spectra (Fig. 8a) for steady state reaction. The impact of CO on NH3 adsorption on both the MnCe/Ti catalyst and the Mn/Ti catalyst (for comparison) was further studied. DRIFT spectra (Fig. 4d) of Mn/Ti catalyst pretreated in different flows indicates that CO markedly inhibited NH3 adsorption on Mn/Ti catalyst. However, on MnCe/Ti catalyst CO did not affect the adsorption of NH3 under transient and steady state reactions. Beside, CO cannot hinder the adsorption of NO on MnCe/Ti catalyst under steady state reaction (Fig. 8b), though it remarkably restrained the adsorption of NO on MnCe/Ti catalyst under NO + CO + O2 flow (Fig. 5). On MnCe/Ti catalyst the carbonate species were not created in the presence of NH3 whereas they appeared when exposure to NO + CO + O2, suggesting that NH3, rather than NO, can inhibit CO to adsorb on MnCe/Ti to generate carbonate species. Therefore, CO is unable to adsorb on MnCe/Ti to generate carbonate under steady state reaction and thus cannot affect the adsorption of NO. Furthermore, the reaction with adsorbed NH3 and NO or nitrate was not affected by gaseous CO. Interestingly, gaseous CO is incapable of undergoing a reaction with the adsorbed nitrate on the MnCe/Ti catalyst. In general, the process of gaseous CO reacting with the adsorbed nitrate on SCR catalysts can take place [37,39,41]. These evidence obviously that CO cannot interact with adsorbed nitrate and MnCe/Ti catalyst surface but only with surface adsorbed oxygen, resulting in the strong resistance of MnCe/Ti catalyst to CO. However, the individual CO can be adsorbed on MnCe/Ti catalyst surface in the absence of NH3. On Mn/Ti catalyst NH3 and CO can be simultaneously adsorbed while only NH3 can be adsorbed on MnCe/Ti catalyst (Fig. 4), pointing to that the introduction of Ce regulated the surface acidity of Mn/Ti catalyst. The performance experiment results suggested that the CO can be oxidized to CO2 when passing through the MnCe/Ti catalyst. This indicates that there are different active sites on the surface of MnCe/Ti catalyst, such as adsorption sites and catalytic oxidation sites. CO can be adsorbed on adsorption sites to form carbonate species on catalyst surface and on catalytic oxidation sites to generate CO2 which can desorb from the surface. However, NH3 is easier to adsorb on adsorption sites in comparison to CO, which can occupy the adsorption sites. This resulted in that CO can only adsorb on catalytic oxidation sites to form CO2 and thus there is no carbonate species appeared on MnCe/Ti catalyst in the presence of NH3. Therefore, the surface acidity of MnCe/Ti catalyst not the properties of CO/NH3 is mainly responsible for the inhibition effect on CO adsorption. This inhibition effect was also found over other catalysts [12,42]. This indicates that the surface acidity of MnCe/Ti catalyst may be improved after Ce doping, which enhances its adsorption ability for NH3 and reduces the interaction between CO and MnCe/Ti catalyst. As a result, the decrease in NO x conversion is primarily ascribed to the decline in surface adsorbed oxygen caused by the oxidation of CO. Scheme 1 illustrates the reaction mechanisms of NO reduction and CO oxidation on MnCe/Ti catalyst. NH3-SCR process primarily occurs through an E-R mechanism, involving the reaction with NO and adsorbed NH3. NH3 completely prevents the CO adsorption on MnCe/Ti catalyst, thereby inhibiting the formation of carbonate species and having no impact on the adsorption of NH3 and NO. CO oxidation occurs through the reaction with CO and surface adsorbed oxygen, following the Mars-van Krevelen (M-vK) mechanism [2,43,44] in which oxygen vacancies generated upon reduction of Mn4+ and Ce4+ by CO adjacent to the resulting Mn3+ and Ce3+ sites are replenished by gaseous O2 during reoxidation of the latter. 5 Conclusions The modified MnM/Ti (M=Ce, Fe, and Co) catalysts are developed for eliminating NO from sintering flue gas, in which MnCe/Ti catalyst exhibits best catalytic performance. The best MnCe/Ti catalyst demonstrates a NO x conversion exceeding 80 % from 125 to 250 °C at a GHSV of 80,000 h−1. NO x conversion decreased by only a 4 % and N2 selectivity increased after the introduction of CO. The CO oxidation over the MnCe/Ti catalyst did not reduce the content of Mn4+ and Ce3+ sites and thus did not reduce the active sites. However, the presence of CO caused a further drop in surface adsorbed oxygen because the oxygen species consumed by CO oxidation cannot be readily replenished as a result of the limited capacity for oxygen and electron transport, which is primarily accountable for the increase in N2 selectivity and the slight decline in NO x conversion. Furthermore, NH3 completely inhibits CO to be adsorbed on MnCe/Ti to generate carbonate species and thus it does not hinder the adsorption of NO and NH3 during SCR reaction. CO does not interact with the adsorbed nitrate because the interaction between CO and MnCe/Ti catalyst weakened due to the improved surface acidity of MnCe/Ti catalyst resulting from Ce doping. On MnCe/Ti catalyst NH3-SCR primarily occurs through an E-R mechanism involving the reaction with NO and adsorbed NH3, while CO oxidation follows a M-vK mechanism including the reaction with CO and surface adsorbed oxygen. coredata.dc:description: The effect of metal doping (Ce, Fe, and Co) on CO tolerance of Mn/Ti catalyst used for eliminating NO from sintering flue gas has been investigated. The best MnCe/Ti catalyst achieves a NO x conversion of 80 % from 125 to 250 °C at a GHSV of 80,000 h−1. NO x conversion dropped by only 4 % below 200 °C and N2 selectivity slightly increased after introduction of CO, indicating strong resistance of MnCe/Ti catalyst to CO. XPS results suggest that CO oxidation does not alter surface content of Mn4+ and Ce3+ sites of used MnCe/Ti catalyst while it reduces the surface adsorbed oxygen of used MnCe/Ti catalyst because surface adsorbed oxygen consumed by CO oxidation cannot be readily replenished owing to the insufficient capacity in oxygen and electron transport. This is primarily accountable for the slight decrease in NO x conversion. Furthermore, NH3 can completely restrain CO adsorption on MnCe/Ti catalyst while CO cannot hinder the adsorption of NH3 and NO on the catalyst because the interaction between CO and MnCe/Ti catalyst significantly weakened in the presence of NH3, leading to the strong CO tolerance of MnCe/Ti. On MnCe/Ti Eley-Rideal mechanism governs the NH3-SCR involving gaseous NO and adsorbed NH3, while Mars-van Krevelen mechanism describes the oxidation of CO, indicating its reaction with gaseous CO and surface adsorbed oxygen. The findings in this paper can provide modification strategy for low-temperature SCR catalysts which are expected to be applied for sintering flue gas.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient MnCe/Ti catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO from sintering flue gas at low temperature: CO tolerance and reaction mechanism assessed by in situ DRIFTS
